heading: Births
txt: Jacob Cats, Dutch poet, jurist, and politician (d. 1660)

entities.title: Jacob Cats
entities.description: Jacob Cats was a Dutch poet, humorist, jurist and politician. He is most famous for his emblem books.

heading: Births
txt: Catherine of Sweden, Countess Palatine of Kleeburg (d. 1638)

entities.title: Catherine of Sweden, Countess Palatine of Kleeburg
entities.description: Catherine of Sweden was a Swedish princess and a Countess Palatine of Zweibrücken as the consort of her second cousin John Casimir of Palatinate-Zweibrücken. She is known as the periodical foster-mother of Queen Christina of Sweden and the mother of Charles X of Sweden.

heading: Births
txt: Ninon de l'Enclos, French courtier and author (d. 1705)

entities.title: Ninon de l'Enclos
entities.description: Anne "Ninon" de l'Enclos, also spelled Ninon de Lenclos and Ninon de Lanclos, was a French author, courtesan and patron of the arts.

heading: Births
txt: François Couperin, French organist and composer (d. 1733)

entities.title: François Couperin
entities.description: François Couperin was a French Baroque composer, organist and harpsichordist. He was known as Couperin le Grand to distinguish him from other members of the musically talented Couperin family.

heading: Births
txt: Louis, Prince of Condé (d. 1710)

heading: Births
txt: John Bevis, English physician and astronomer (d. 1771)

entities.title: John Bevis
entities.description: John Bevis was an English doctor, electrical researcher and astronomer. He is best known for discovering the Crab Nebula in 1731.

heading: Births
txt: William Hogarth, English painter, illustrator, and critic (d. 1764)

entities.title: William Hogarth
entities.description: William Hogarth was an English painter, printmaker, pictorial satirist, social critic, and editorial cartoonist. His work ranges from realistic portraiture to comic strip-like series of pictures called "modern moral subjects", and he is perhaps best known for his series A Harlot's Progress, A Rake's Progress and Marriage A-la-Mode. Knowledge of his work is so pervasive that satirical political ill

heading: Births
txt: Adam Gottlob Moltke, Danish courtier, politician, and diplomat (d. 1792)

entities.title: Adam Gottlob Moltke
entities.description: Count Adam Gottlob von Moltke was a Danish courtier, statesman and diplomat, and Favourite of Frederick V of Denmark. Moltke was born at Riesenhof in Mecklenburg. His son, Joachim Godske Moltke, and his grandson, Adam Wilhelm Moltke, later served as Prime Minister of Denmark.

heading: Births
txt: Oliver Goldsmith, Irish-English author, poet, and playwright (d. 1774)

entities.title: Oliver Goldsmith
entities.description: Oliver Goldsmith was an Anglo-Irish novelist, playwright and poet, who is best known for his novel The Vicar of Wakefield (1766), his pastoral poem The Deserted Village (1770), and his plays The Good-Natur'd Man (1768) and She Stoops to Conquer. He is thought to have written the classic children's tale The History of Little Goody Two-Shoes (1765).

heading: Births
txt: Granville Sharp, English activist and scholar, co-founded the Sierra Leone Company (d. 1813)

entities.title: Granville Sharp
entities.description: Granville Sharp was one of the first British campaigners for the abolition of the slave trade. He also involved himself in trying to correct other social injustices. Sharp formulated the plan to settle black people in Sierra Leone, and founded the St George's Bay Company, a forerunner of the Sierra Leone Company. His efforts led to both the founding of the Province of Freedom, and later on Freetow

entities.title: Sierra Leone Company
entities.description: The Sierra Leone Company was the corporate body involved in founding the second British colony in Africa on 11 March 1792 through the resettlement of Black Loyalists who had initially been settled in Nova Scotia after the American Revolutionary War. The company came about because of the work of the ardent abolitionists, Granville Sharp, Thomas Clarkson, Henry Thornton, and Thomas's brother, John

heading: Births
txt: Franz Anton Ries, German violinist and educator (d. 1846)

entities.title: Franz Anton Ries
entities.description:
Franz Anton Xaverius Ries was a German violinist. His father Johann Ries (1723–1784) was court trumpeter to the Elector of Cologne in Bonn.
Ries was born in Bonn, and studied under J.P. Salomon. He was a child prodigy, and was concertmaster of the Kurfürstlichen Hoforchester in Vienna. He spent most of his life in Bonn, though he had success in his early years in Vienna as both a solo violinist an

heading: Births
txt: Friedrich Schiller, German poet, playwright, and historian (d. 1805)

entities.title: Friedrich Schiller
entities.description: Johann Christoph Friedrich (von) Schiller was a German playwright, poet, and philosopher. During the last seventeen years of his life (1788–1805), Schiller developed a productive, if complicated, friendship with the already famous and influential Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. They frequently discussed issues concerning aesthetics, and Schiller encouraged Goethe to finish works he left as sketches. T

heading: Births
txt: Andrés Manuel del Rio, Spanish-Mexican scientist and discoverer of vanadium (d. 1849)

entities.title: Andrés Manuel del Rio
entities.description: Andrés Manuel del Río y Fernández was a Spanish–Mexican scientist, naturalist and engineer who discovered compounds of vanadium in 1801. He proposed that the element be given the name panchromium, or later, erythronium, but his discovery was not credited at the time, and his names were not used.

heading: Births
txt: Anne-Marie Javouhey, French nun, founder of the Sisters of St Joseph of Cluny (d. 1851)

entities.title: Anne-Marie Javouhey
entities.description: Anne-Marie Javouhey was a French nun who founded the Sisters of Saint Joseph of Cluny. She is venerated in the Roman Catholic Church. She is known as the Liberator of the Slaves in the New World, and as the mother of the town of Mana, French Guiana.

heading: Births
txt: Vladimir Dal, Russian lexicographer and author (d. 1872)

entities.title: Vladimir Dal
entities.description: Vladimir Ivanovich Dal was a noted Russian-language lexicographer, polyglot, Turkologist, and founding member of the Russian Geographical Society. During his lifetime he compiled and documented the oral history of the region that was later published in Russian and became part of modern folklore.

txt: Samuel Gridley Howe, American physician and activist (d. 1876)

heading: Births
txt: George Jennings, English plumber and engineer, invented the flush toilet (d. 1882)

entities.title: George Jennings
entities.description: George Jennings was an English sanitary engineer and plumber who invented the first public flush toilets.

entities.title: Flush toilet
entities.description: A flush toilet is a toilet that disposes of human waste by using water to flush it through a drainpipe to another location for disposal, thus maintaining a separation between humans and their waste. Flush toilets can be designed for sitting or for squatting, in the case of squat toilets. Most modern toilets are designed to dispose of toilet paper also. The opposite of a flush toilet is a dry toile

entities.title: José Hernández (writer)
entities.description: José Hernández was an Argentine journalist, poet, and politician best known as the author of the epic poem Martín Fierro.

entities.title: Henry Eyster Jacobs
entities.description: Henry Eyster Jacobs was an American religious educator, Biblical commentator and Lutheran theologian.

txt: John Sparrow David Thompson, Canadian lawyer, judge, and politician, 4th Prime Minister of Canada (d. 1894)

entities.title: John Sparrow David Thompson
entities.description: Sir John Sparrow David Thompson was a Canadian lawyer, judge, and politician who served as the fourth prime minister of Canada, in office from 1892 until his death. He had previously been premier of Nova Scotia for a brief period in 1882.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Canada
entities.description: The prime minister of Canada is the first minister of the Crown. The prime minister acts as the head of government for Canada, chairs and selects the membership of the Cabinet, and advises the Crown on the exercise of executive power and much of the royal prerogative. As prime ministers hold office by virtue of their ability to command the confidence of the elected House of Commons, they typically

heading: Births
txt: Surendranath Banerjee, Indian academic and politician (d. 1925)

entities.title: Surendranath Banerjee
entities.description: Sir Surendranath Banerjee was one of the earliest Indian political leaders during the British Rule. He founded a nationalist organization called the Indian National Association, through which he led two sessions of the Indian National Conference in 1883 and 1885, along with Anandamohan Bose. Banerjee later became a senior member of the Indian National Congress. Surendranath repudiated Montagu–Chel

heading: Births
txt: Arthur Goring Thomas, English composer (d. 1892)

entities.title: Arthur Goring Thomas
entities.description: Arthur Goring Thomas was an English composer.

heading: Births

entities.title: Richard Armstedt
entities.description: Richard Armstedt was a German philologist, educator, and historian.

txt: Heinrich XXVII, Prince Reuss Younger Line (d. 1928)

entities.title: Heinrich XXVII, Prince Reuss Younger Line
entities.description: Heinrich XXVII, Prince Reuss Younger Line was the last reigning Prince Reuss Younger Line from 1913 to 1918. Then he became Head of the House of Reuss Younger Line from 1918 to 1928.

heading: Births
txt: Gichin Funakoshi, Japanese martial artist and educator, founded Shotokan (d. 1957)

entities.title: Gichin Funakoshi
entities.description: Gichin Funakoshi  is the founder of Shotokan karate-do, perhaps the most widely known style of karate, and is known as a "father of modern karate". Following the teachings of Anko Itosu and Anko Asato, he was one of the Okinawan karate masters who introduced karate, but after Ankō Itosu sensei, Funakoshi sensei's teacher, had introduced the art pre-1922, to the Japanese mainland in 1922. He taught

entities.title: Shotokan
entities.description: Shotokan  is a style of karate, developed from various martial arts by Gichin Funakoshi (1868–1957) and his son Gigo (Yoshitaka) Funakoshi (1906–1945). Gichin Funakoshi was born in Okinawa and is widely credited with popularizing "karate do" through a series of public demonstrations, and by promoting the development of university karate clubs, including those at Keio, Waseda, Hitotsubashi (Shodai)

heading: Births
txt: Gaetano Bresci, Italian-American assassin of Umberto I of Italy (d. 1901)

entities.title: Gaetano Bresci
entities.description: Gaetano Bresci was an Italian anarchist who assassinated King Umberto I of Italy on July 29, 1900. Bresci was the first European regicide offender not to be executed, as capital punishment in Italy had been abolished in 1889.

entities.title: Umberto I of Italy
entities.description: Umberto I, nicknamed the Good, was the King of Italy from 9 January 1878 until his assassination on 29 July 1900.

heading: Births
txt: Winston Churchill, American author and painter (d. 1947)

entities.title: Winston Churchill (novelist)
entities.description: Winston Churchill was an American best-selling novelist of the early 20th century.

entities.title: Henri Rabaud
entities.description: Henri Benjamin Rabaud was a French conductor, composer and pedagogue, who held important posts in the French musical establishment and upheld mainly conservative trends in French music in the first half of the twentieth century.

entities.title: Idabelle Smith Firestone
entities.description: Idabelle Smith Firestone was an American composer and songwriter.

heading: Births
txt: Vachel Lindsay, American poet and educator (d. 1931)

entities.title: Vachel Lindsay
entities.description: Nicholas Vachel Lindsay was an American poet. He is considered a founder of modern singing poetry, as he referred to it, in which verses are meant to be sung or chanted.

heading: Births
txt: Patrick Pearse, Irish lawyer, poet, teacher, and insurrectionist; executed for his role in the Easter Rising (d. 1916)

entities.title: Easter Rising
entities.description: The Easter Rising, also known as the Easter Rebellion, was an armed insurrection in Ireland during Easter Week in April 1916. The Rising was launched by Irish republicans against British rule in Ireland with the aim of establishing an independent Irish Republic while the United Kingdom was fighting the First World War. It was the most significant uprising in Ireland since the rebellion of 1798 and

heading: Births
txt: Jacob Epstein, American-English sculptor (d. 1959)

entities.title: Jacob Epstein
entities.description: Sir Jacob Epstein was an American-British sculptor who helped pioneer modern sculpture. He was born in the United States, and moved to Europe in 1902, becoming a British subject in 1911. He often produced controversial works which challenged ideas on what was appropriate subject matter for public artworks. He also made paintings and drawings, and often exhibited his work.

heading: Births
txt: Zofia Nałkowska, Polish author and playwright (d. 1954)

entities.title: Zofia Nałkowska
entities.description: Zofia Nałkowska was a Polish prose writer, dramatist, and prolific essayist. She served as the executive member of the prestigious Polish Academy of Literature (1933–1939) during the interwar period.

heading: Births
txt: Edward Joseph Collins, American pianist, composer, and conductor (d. 1951)

entities.title: Edward Joseph Collins
entities.description: Edward Joseph Collins was an American pianist, conductor and composer of classical music in a neoromantic style.

heading: Births
txt: Elisa Leonida Zamfirescu, Romanian engineer and academic (d. 1973)

entities.title: Elisa Leonida Zamfirescu
entities.description: Elisa Leonida Zamfirescu was a Romanian engineer who was one of the first women to obtain a degree in engineering. She was born in the Romanian town of Galați but qualified in Berlin. During World War I she managed a hospital in Romania.

entities.title: Andrei Tupolev
entities.description: Andrei Nikolayevich Tupolev was a Soviet aeronautical engineer known for his pioneering aircraft designs as Director of the Tupolev Design Bureau.

entities.title: Tupolev
entities.description: Tupolev, officially Joint Stock Company Tupolev, is a Russian aerospace and defence company headquartered in Basmanny District, Moscow.

heading: Births
txt: Claude Rains, English-American actor (d. 1967)

entities.title: Claude Rains
entities.description: William Claude Rains was a British-American film and stage actor whose career spanned almost seven decades. After his American film debut as Dr. Jack Griffin in The Invisible Man (1933), he appeared in such highly regarded films as The Adventures of Robin Hood (1938), Mr. Smith Goes to Washington (1939), The Wolf Man (1941), Casablanca and Kings Row, Notorious (1946), Lawrence of Arabia (1962), an

heading: Births
txt: Carl Stalling, American pianist and composer (d. 1972)

entities.title: Carl Stalling
entities.description: Carl W. Stalling was an American composer and arranger for music in animated films. He is most closely associated with the Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies shorts produced by Warner Bros., where he averaged one complete score each week, for 22 years.

heading: Births
txt: John P. Marquand, American author (d. 1960)

entities.title: John P. Marquand
entities.description: John Phillips Marquand was an American writer. Originally best known for his Mr. Moto spy stories, he achieved popular success and critical respect for his satirical novels, winning a Pulitzer Prize for The Late George Apley in 1938. heading: Births
txt: Boris Furlan, Slovenian lawyer, jurist, and politician (d. 1957)

entities.title: Boris Furlan
entities.description: Boris Furlan was a Slovenian jurist, philosopher of law, translator and liberal politician. During World War II, he worked as a speaker on Radio London, and was known as "London's Slovene voice". He served as a Minister in the Tito–Šubašić coalition government. In 1947, he was convicted by the Yugoslav Communist authorities at the Nagode Trial.

heading: Births
txt: József Mátyás Baló, Hungarian physician and academic (d. 1979)

entities.title: József Mátyás Baló
entities.description: József Mátyás Baló was a Hungarian physician and academic. He researched extensively into neurological conditions, cardiovascular conditions and with his wife isolated the enzyme elastase. He published numerous related papers and authored a medical book. He gave his name to Baló's Disease.

heading: Births
txt: Jack Northrop, American businessman, founded the Northrop Corporation (d. 1981)

entities.title: Northrop Corporation
entities.description: Northrop Corporation was an American aircraft manufacturer from its formation in 1939 until its 1994 merger with Grumman to form Northrop Grumman. The company is known for its development of the flying wing design, most successfully the B-2 Spirit stealth bomber.

heading: Births
txt: Jimmy Dykes, American baseball player and manager (d. 1976)

entities.title: Jimmy Dykes
entities.description: James Joseph Dykes was an American professional baseball player, coach and manager. He played in Major League Baseball as a third and second baseman from 1918 through 1939, most notably as a member of the Philadelphia Athletics dynasty that won three consecutive American League pennants from 1929 to 1931 and, won the World Series in 1929 and 1930. He played his final six seasons for the Chicago Wh

heading: Births
txt: Kate Seredy, Hungarian-American author and illustrator (d. 1975)

entities.title: Kate Seredy
entities.description: Kate Seredy was a Hungarian-born writer and illustrator of children's books. She won the Newbery Medal once, the Newbery Honor twice, the Caldecott Honor once, and Lewis Carroll Shelf Award. Most of her books were written in English, which was not her first language. Seredy seems to be unknown in her native Hungary, despite the fact that her story of the Good Master, and the sequel set in World Wa

heading: Births
txt: Josef Kramer, German SS officer (d. 1945)

entities.title: Josef Kramer
entities.description: Josef Kramer was the Commandant of Auschwitz-Birkenau and of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. Dubbed the Beast of Belsen by camp inmates, he was a German Nazi war criminal, directly responsible for the deaths of thousands of people. He was detained by the British Army after the Second World War, convicted of war crimes and hanged on the gallows in the prison at Hamelin by British executioner

entities.title: SS
entities.description: The Schutzstaffel was a major paramilitary organization under Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party in Nazi Germany, and later throughout German-occupied Europe during World War II. It began with a small guard unit known as the Saal-Schutz made up of party volunteers to provide security for party meetings in Munich. heading: Births
txt: Jane Froman, American actress and singer (d. 1980)

entities.title: Jane Froman
entities.description: Ellen Jane Froman was an American singer and actress. During her thirty-year career, Froman performed on stage, radio and television despite chronic health problems due to injuries sustained in a 1943 plane crash.

It is awarded for valour "in the presence of the enemy" to members of the British Armed Forces. It may be awarded posthumously. entities.description: Paweł Jasienica was the pen name of Leon Lech Beynar, a Polish historian, journalist, essayist and soldier.

He also exhibited his works in New York City and Washington DC, where he was received by president Lyndon Johnson. Angelo Frattini died in Varese on September 2, 1975. heading: Births
txt: Birdie Tebbetts, American baseball player and manager (d. 1999)

entities.title: Birdie Tebbetts
entities.description: George Robert "Birdie" Tebbetts was an American professional baseball player, manager, scout and front office executive. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) as a catcher for the Detroit Tigers, Boston Red Sox and the Cleveland Indians from 1936 to 1952. Tebbets was regarded as the best catcher in the American League in the late 1940s.

entities.title: Karl Shapiro
entities.description: Karl Jay Shapiro was an American poet. He was appointed the fifth Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress in 1946.

entities.description: Louis le Brocquy HRHA was an Irish painter born in Dublin to Albert and Sybil le Brocquy. heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Leo I (b. 400)

entities.title: Pope Leo I
entities.description: Leo I, also known as Leo the Great, was Bishop of Rome from 29 September 440 until his death. Pope Benedict XVI said that Leo's papacy "was undoubtedly one of the most important in the Church's history."

heading: Deaths
txt: Leo II, Byzantine emperor (b. 467)

entities.title: Leo II (emperor)
entities.description: Leo II, nicknamed "the Younger" or "the Small", was briefly Roman emperor in 474 when he was a child aged six or seven. He was the son of Zeno, the Isaurian general and future emperor, and Ariadne, a daughter of the emperor Leo I, who ruled the eastern Roman empire. Leo II was made co-emperor with his grandfather Leo I on 17 November 473, and became sole emperor on 18 January 474 after Leo I died

heading: Deaths
txt: Justus, Italian-English archbishop and saint

entities.title: Justus
entities.description: Justus was the fourth Archbishop of Canterbury. He was sent from Italy to England by Pope Gregory the Great, on a mission to Christianize the Anglo-Saxons from their native paganism, probably arriving with the second group of missionaries despatched in 601. Justus became the first Bishop of Rochester in 604, and attended a church council in Paris in 614.

heading: Deaths
txt: Adelaide of Paris (b. 850)

entities.title: Adelaide of Paris
entities.description: Adélaïde of Paris was a Frankish queen. She was the second wife of Louis the Stammerer, King of West Francia, and was the mother of Charles the Simple.

heading: Deaths
txt: Zhao Yanshou, Chinese general and governor

entities.title: Zhao Yanshou
entities.description: Zhao Yanshou, né Liu Yanshou (劉延壽), formally the Prince of Wei (魏王), was a major general of Later Tang of the Chinese Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms Period, as well as the Khitan Liao Dynasty. He first became prominent as a son-in-law of Later Tang's second emperor Li Siyuan, but was captured by Liao's Emperor Taizong when Later Tang fell. He subsequently served Emperor Taizong, who promised him

heading: Deaths
txt: John Scotus, bishop of Mecklenburg

entities.title: John Scotus (bishop of Mecklenburg)
entities.description: John Scotus was a Bishop of Mecklenburg from Scotland. It is likely this John can be identified as the John who was allegedly made Bishop of Glasgow sometime between 1055 and 1060 and possibly the same John allegedly holding the title of Bishop of Orkney.

heading: Deaths
txt: Agnes of Burgundy, Duchess of Aquitaine, regent of Aquitaine

entities.title: Agnes of Burgundy, Duchess of Aquitaine
entities.description:
Agnes of Burgundy was Duchess of Aquitaine by marriage to Duke William V and Countess of Anjou by marriage to Count Geoffrey II. She served as regent of the Duchy of Aquitaine during the minority of her son from 1039 until 1044. 
She was a daughter of Otto-William, Count of Burgundy and Ermentrude de Roucy and a member of the House of Ivrea.

heading: Deaths
txt: Guðrøðr Óláfsson, King of the Isles

entities.title: Guðrøðr Óláfsson
entities.description: Guðrøðr Óláfsson was a twelfth-century ruler of the kingdoms of Dublin and the Isles. Guðrøðr was a son of Óláfr Guðrøðarson, King of the Isles and Affraic, daughter of Fergus, Lord of Galloway. Throughout his career, Guðrøðr battled rival claimants to the throne, permanently losing about half of his realm to a rival dynasty in the process. Although dethroned for nearly a decade, Guðrøðr clawed hi

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Celestine IV

entities.title: Pope Celestine IV
entities.description: Pope Celestine IV, born Goffredo da Castiglione, was Bishop of Rome and as such head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States for only a few days from 25 October 1241 to his death.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: William de Bondington
entities.description: William de Bondington was a 13th-century Chancellor of Scotland and a bishop of Glasgow.

heading: Deaths

entities.description: Isabel de Forz was the eldest daughter of Baldwin de Redvers, 6th Earl of Devon (1217–1245). On the death of her brother Baldwin de Redvers, 7th Earl of Devon in 1262, without children, she inherited suo jure the earldom and also the feudal barony of Plympton in Devon, and the Lordship of the Isle of Wight. After the early death of her husband and her brother, before she was thirty years old, she

heading: Deaths
txt: John I, Count of Holland (b. 1284)

entities.title: John I, Count of Holland
entities.description: John I was Count of Holland and son of Count Floris V. John inherited the county in 1296 after the murder of his father.

heading: Deaths
txt: Władysław III of Poland (b. 1424)

entities.title: Władysław III of Poland
entities.description: Władysław III, also known as Władysław of Varna, was King of Poland and the Supreme Duke of Grand Duchy of Lithuania from 1434 and King of Hungary and Croatia from 1440 until his death at the Battle of Varna. He was the eldest son of Władysław II Jagiełło, King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania, and the Lithuanian noblewoman Sophia of Halshany.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Paul III (b. 1468)

entities.title: Pope Paul III
entities.description: Pope Paul III, born Alessandro Farnese, was head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 13 October 1534 to his death in 1549.

entities.title: Richard Chancellor
entities.description: Richard Chancellor was an English explorer and navigator; the first to penetrate to the White Sea and establish relations with the Tsardom of Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Barnabe Rich, English soldier and author (b. 1540)

entities.title: Barnabe Rich
entities.description: Barnabe Rich, was an English author and soldier, and a distant relative of Lord Chancellor Rich.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton
entities.description: Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton, , was the only son of Henry Wriothesley, 2nd Earl of Southampton, and Mary Browne, daughter of Anthony Browne, 1st Viscount Montagu. Shakespeare's two narrative poems, Venus and Adonis and The Rape of Lucrece, were dedicated to Southampton, who is frequently identified as the Fair Youth of Shakespeare's Sonnets.

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Hampshire
entities.description: This is a list of people who have served as Lord Lieutenant of Hampshire. Since 1688, all the Lords Lieutenant have also been Custos Rotulorum of Hampshire. From 1889 until 1959, the administrative county was named the County of Southampton.

heading: Deaths
txt: Luis Vélez de Guevara, Spanish author and playwright (b. 1579)

entities.title: Luis Vélez de Guevara
entities.description:
Luis Vélez de Guevara was a Spanish dramatist and novelist.
He was born at Écija and was of Jewish converso descent.
After graduating as a sizar at the University of Osuna in 1596, he joined the household of Rodrigo de Castro, Cardinal-Archbishop of Seville, and celebrated the marriage of Philip III in a poem signed Vélez de Santander, a name which he continued to use till some years later.

heading: Deaths
txt: Afzal Khan, Indian commander

entities.title: Afzal Khan (general)
entities.description: Afzal Khan was a general who served the Adil Shahi dynasty of Bijapur Sultanate in India. He played an important role in the southern expansion of the Bijapur Sultanate by subjugating the Nayaka chiefs who had taken control of the former Vijayanagara territory.

heading: Deaths
txt: Michał Korybut Wiśniowiecki, King of Poland (b. 1640)

entities.title: Michał Korybut Wiśniowiecki
entities.description: Michael I was the ruler of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth as King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania from 29 September 1669 until his death in 1673.

entities.description: Pierre Alphonse de Tonty, or Alphonse de Tonty, Baron de Paludy was an officer who served under the French explorer Cadillac and helped establish the first European settlement at Detroit, Michigan, Fort Pontchartrain du Detroit on the Detroit River in 1701. Several months later, both Cadillac and Tonty brought their wives to the fort, making them the first European women to travel so deep into the

heading: Deaths
txt: Fyodor Apraksin, Russian admiral (b. 1661)

entities.title: Fyodor Apraksin
entities.description: Count Fyodor Matveyevich Apraksin was one of the first Russian admirals, governed Estonia and Karelia from 1712 to 1723, was made general admiral (1708), presided over the Russian Admiralty from 1718 and commanded the Baltic Fleet from 1723.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pedro Correia Garção, Portuguese poet and author (b. 1724)

entities.title: Pedro Correia Garção
entities.description: Pedro António Joaquim Correia da Serra Garção was a Portuguese lyric poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cornstalk, American tribal chief (b. 1720)

entities.title: Cornstalk
entities.description: Cornstalk was a prominent Shawnee leader in the Ohio Country in the 1760s and 1770s. His name in the Shawnee language was Hokoleskwa. Little is known about his early life. He may have been born in the Province of Pennsylvania. In 1763, he reportedly led a raid against British-American colonists in Pontiac's War. He first appears in historical documents in 1764, when he was one of the hostages surr

heading: Deaths
txt: Guy Carleton, 1st Baron Dorchester, Irish-born English general and politician, 21st Governor General of Canada (b. 1724)

entities.title: Guy Carleton, 1st Baron Dorchester
entities.description: Guy Carleton, 1st Baron Dorchester, known between 1776 and 1786 as Sir Guy Carleton, was an Anglo-Irish soldier and administrator. He twice served as Governor of the Province of Quebec, from 1768 to 1778, concurrently serving as Governor General of British North America in that time, and again from 1785 to 1795. The title Baron Dorchester was created on 21 August 1786.

entities.title: Governor General of Canada
entities.description: The governor general of Canada is the federal viceregal representative of the Canadian monarch, currently Queen Elizabeth II. The Queen, as a political sovereign, is shared equally with the 15 other Commonwealth realms and the 10 provinces of Canada, but she physically resides predominantly in her oldest and most populous realm, the United Kingdom. The Queen, on the advice of her Canadian prime mi

heading: Deaths
txt: Gideon Mantell, English scientist (b. 1790)

entities.title: Gideon Mantell
entities.description: Gideon Algernon Mantell MRCS FRS was an English obstetrician, geologist and palaeontologist. His attempts to reconstruct the structure and life of Iguanodon began the scientific study of dinosaurs: in 1822 he was responsible for the discovery of the first fossil teeth, and later much of the skeleton, of Iguanodon. Mantell's work on the Cretaceous of southern England was also important.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Wirz, Swiss-American captain in Confederate army, commandant of Andersonville Prison (b. 1823)

entities.title: Henry Wirz
entities.description: Heinrich Hartmann "Henry" Wirz was a Swiss-American officer of the Confederate Army during the American Civil War. Wirz was the commandant of the stockade of Camp Sumter, a Confederate prisoner-of-war camp near Andersonville, Georgia, where inhumane conditions led to a high mortality rate of Union detainees. After the war, Wirz was tried and executed for conspiracy and murder relating to his comma

entities.title: Andersonville National Historic Site
entities.description: The Andersonville National Historic Site, located near Andersonville, Georgia, preserves the former Andersonville Prison, a Confederate prisoner-of-war camp during the final fourteen months of the American Civil War. Most of the site lies in southwestern Macon County, adjacent to the east side of the town of Andersonville. As well as the former prison, the site contains the Andersonville National

heading: Deaths
txt: John E. Wool, American general (b. 1784)

entities.title: John E. Wool
entities.description: John Ellis Wool was an officer in the United States Army during three consecutive U.S. wars: the War of 1812, the Mexican–American War and the American Civil War. By the time of the Mexican-American War, he was widely considered one of the most capable officers in the army and a superb organizer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maria Jane Williams, Welsh musician and folklorist (b. circa 1794)

entities.title: Maria Jane Williams
entities.description: Maria Jane Williams was a 19th-century Welsh musician and folklorist born at Aberpergwm House, Glynneath in Glamorgan, South Wales. She rescued many Welsh songs from obscurity, including Y Deryn Pur  and Y Ferch o'r Sger.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Lingg, German-American carpenter and activist (b. 1864)

entities.title: Louis Lingg
entities.description: Louis Lingg was a German-born American anarchist who committed suicide while in jail after being convicted and sentenced to hang as a member of a criminal conspiracy behind the Haymarket Square bombing. Lingg committed suicide in his cell with an explosive shortly before his scheduled execution.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Rimbaud, French poet and educator (b. 1854)

entities.title: Arthur Rimbaud
entities.description: Jean Nicolas Arthur Rimbaud was a French poet known for his transgressive and surreal themes, and his influence on modern literature and arts, prefiguring surrealism. Born in Charleville, he started writing at a very young age and excelled as a student, but abandoned his formal education in his teenage years to run away from home to Paris amidst the Franco-Prussian War. During his late adolescence

heading: Deaths
txt: George Essex Evans, Australian poet and educator (b. 1863)

entities.title: George Essex Evans
entities.description: George Essex Evans was an Australian poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anita Berber, German dancer (b. 1899)

entities.title: Anita Berber
entities.description: Anita Berber was a German dancer, actress, and writer who was the subject of an Otto Dix painting. She lived during the time of the Weimar Republic.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Gustave Binger, French general and explorer (b. 1856)

entities.title: Louis Gustave Binger
entities.description: Louis-Gustave Binger was a French officer and explorer who claimed the Côte d'Ivoire for France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, Turkish field marshal and statesman, 1st President of Turkey (b. 1881)

entities.title: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk
entities.description: Kemal Atatürk was a Turkish field marshal, revolutionary statesman, author, and the founding father of the Republic of Turkey, serving as its first president from 1923 until his death in 1938. He undertook sweeping progressive reforms, which modernized Turkey into a secular, industrial nation. Ideologically a secularist and nationalist, his policies and theories became known as Kemalism. Due to hi

entities.title: President of Turkey
entities.description: The president of the Republic of Turkey is the head of state and, following the 2017 Turkish constitutional referendum, also head of government of the Republic of Turkey.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carrie Derick, Canadian botanist and geneticist (b. 1862)

entities.title: Carrie Derick
entities.description: Carrie Matilda Derick was a Canadian botanist and geneticist, the first female professor in a Canadian university, and the founder of McGill University's Genetics Department.

heading: Deaths
txt: Claude Rodier physicist (b.1903)

entities.title: Claude Rodier
entities.description: Claude Rodier was a physicist, teacher and staff sergeant in the Mouvements Unis de la Résistance (MUR), part of the French Resistance in Auvergne, France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Zutter, Swiss gymnast (b. 1856)

entities.title: Louis Zutter
entities.description: Louis Arnold Zutter was a Swiss gymnast. He competed at the 1896 Summer Olympics in Athens.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gordon MacQuarrie, American author and journalist (b. 1900)

entities.title: Gordon MacQuarrie
entities.description: Gordon MacQuarrie was an American writer and journalist. Born in Superior, Wisconsin, he is best known for his short stories involving hunting and fishing, and for his semi-fictional organization known as The Old Duck Hunters' Association, Inc.(ODHA, Inc.) He died unexpectedly in Milwaukee, Wisconsin of a heart attack.

heading: Deaths
txt: Julius Lenhart, Austrian gymnast and engineer (b. 1875)

entities.title: Julius Lenhart
entities.description: Julius Lenhart was an Austrian gymnast who competed in the 1904 Summer Olympics. He won two gold medals and one silver medal, making him the most successful Austrian competitor ever at the Summer Olympic Games.

heading: Deaths
txt: Klara Dan von Neumann, Hungarian-American computer scientist (b. 1911)

entities.title: Klara Dan von Neumann
entities.description: Klára (Klari) Dán von Neumann was a Hungarian-American computer scientist, noted as one of the first computer programmers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Van Tilburg Clark, American author and academic (b. 1909)

entities.title: Walter Van Tilburg Clark
entities.description: Walter Van Tilburg Clark was an American novelist, short story writer, and educator. He ranks as one of Nevada's most distinguished literary figures of the 20th century, and was the first inductee into the 'Nevada Writers Hall of Fame' in 1988, together with Robert Laxalt, Clark's mentee and Nevada's other heralded twentieth century author. Two of Clark's novels, The Ox-Bow Incident and The Track

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernest M. McSorley, Canadian-American captain (b. 1912)

entities.title: Ernest M. McSorley
entities.description: Ernest Michael McSorley was the last captain of the ill-fated Laker-type freighter SS Edmund Fitzgerald. McSorley died along with the other 28 members of his crew when the Fitzgerald sank in Lake Superior on November 10, 1975.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leonid Brezhnev, Ukrainian-Russian general and politician, 4th Head of State of the Soviet Union (b. 1906)

entities.title: Leonid Brezhnev
entities.description: Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev was a Soviet politician who led the Soviet Union as General Secretary of the governing Communist Party (1964–1982) and as Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet. His 18-year term as general secretary was second only to Joseph Stalin's in duration. While Brezhnev's rule was characterised by political stability and notable foreign policy successes, it was also marked

entities.title: List of heads of state of the Soviet Union
entities.description: The Constitution of the Soviet Union recognised the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet and the earlier Central Executive Committee (CEC) of the Congress of Soviets as the highest organs of state authority in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). Under the 1924, 1936 and 1977 Soviet Constitutions these bodies served as the collective head of state of the Soviet Union. The Chairman of these b

heading: Deaths
txt: Xavier Herbert, Australian author (b. 1901)

entities.title: Xavier Herbert
entities.description: Xavier Herbert was an Australian writer best known for his Miles Franklin Award-winning novel Poor Fellow My Country (1975). He is considered one of the elder statesmen of Australian literature. He is also known for short story collections and his autobiography Disturbing Element.

entities.description: Regidor de la Rosa, professionally known as Rogelio de la Rosa, was one of the most popular Filipino matinee idols of the 20th century. He is also remembered for his statesmanship, in particular his accomplishments as a diplomat. entities.description: Noor Hossain was a Bangladeshi activist who was killed by the Bangladesh Police on November 10, 1987, while protesting against President Hussain Muhammad Ershad near Zero Point in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Zero Point was later renamed Noor Hossain Square and the anniversary of his death is officially commemorated each year as Shohid Noor Hossain Day. He was a fifteen-time world champion in professional wrestling, having held the AWA World Heavyweight Championship, the WWA World Heavyweight Championship thirteen times and the WWA World Heavyweight Championship once.

entities.title: Chuck Connors
entities.description: Kevin Joseph Aloysius "Chuck" Connors was an American actor, writer, and professional basketball and baseball player. He is one of only 13 athletes in the history of American professional sports to have played both Major League Baseball and in the National Basketball Association. With a 40-year film and television career, he is best known for his five-year role as Lucas McCain in the highly rated

heading: Deaths
txt: Carmen McRae, American singer, pianist, and actress (b. 1920)

entities.title: Carmen McRae
entities.description: Carmen Mercedes McRae was an American jazz singer. She is considered one of the most influential jazz vocalists of the 20th century and is remembered for her behind-the-beat phrasing and ironic interpretation of lyrics.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Ken Saro-Wiwa
entities.description: Kenule Beeson "Ken" Saro-Wiwa was a Nigerian writer, television producer, environmental activist. Saro-Wiwa was a member of the Ogoni people, an ethnic minority in Nigeria whose homeland, Ogoniland, in the Niger Delta has been targeted for crude oil extraction since the 1950s and which has suffered extreme environmental damage from decades of indiscriminate petroleum waste dumping.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Mary Millar
entities.description: Irene Mary Wetton, better known by her stage name Mary Millar, was an English actress and singer best remembered for her role as the second actress to play Rose in the highly successful BBC sitcom Keeping Up Appearances between 1991 and 1995.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Adamantios Androutsopoulos
entities.description: Adamantios Androutsopoulos was a lawyer and professor. He held various ministerial posts under the Greek military junta of 1967–1974 and was finally appointed 168th Prime Minister of Greece from 1973 to 1974 by junta strongman Dimitrios Ioannides.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Canaan Banana, Zimbabwean minister and politician, 1st President of Zimbabwe (b. 1936)

entities.title: Canaan Banana
entities.description: Canaan Sodindo Banana was a Zimbabwean Methodist minister, theologian, and politician who served as the first President of Zimbabwe from 1980 to 1987. He was Zimbabwe's first head of state after the Lancaster House Agreement that led to the country’s independence. In 1987, he stepped down as President and was succeeded by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, who became the country's executive president.

entities.title: President of Zimbabwe
entities.description: The President of Zimbabwe is the highest office in the executive branch of the country's government. The president is head of state of Zimbabwe, elected by direct universal suffrage using a two-round system. Formerly a ceremonial role, the president is now also the head of government. The president serves a maximum of two five-year terms.

He is most famous for his songs Ik Wil deze Nacht in de Straten Verdwalen (1973), Mijn Mansarde and De Brug van Willebroek (1990). His work is often categorized as kleinkunst. entities.description: Agostino "Dino" De Laurentiis was an Italian film producer. He produced or co-produced more than 500 films, of which 38 were nominated for Academy Awards. He also had a brief acting career in the late 1930s and early 1940s.
